title: Southern Colorado county declares disaster because of massive snow drifts, high winds

text:
Caldara: Rich, white welfare queens 
A southern Colorado county declared a disaster Tuesday because of heavy snow and strong winds, which were combining to create dangerous conditions. 
“The high winds are causing snow drifts as high as ten feet in some places, and we want to make sure our citizens are safe,” Christopher Rodriguez, Costilla County’s emergency manager, said in a statement. 
Officials say Centennial School District in the county’s San Luis Valley was closed Tuesday and will be shuttered Wednesday as well. 
The Colorado Division of Homeland Security and Emergency Management says it has opened its emergency operations center to help Costilla County and Dolores County in southwest Colorado, which is also being pounded by heavy snow. The State EOC activated to support Castillo and Dolores County due to #COwx impacts. pic.twitter.com/eQj06t4KFa 
— CO – Emergency Mgmt (@COEmergency) January 24, 2017 
The National Weather Service in Pueblo reported heavy snow squalls moving through the San Luis Valley on Tuesday. 
Costilla County officials say they have called for assistance from other jurisdictions within the San Luis Valley, as well as state resources, to work on clearing roads and checking on residents who may be stuck and need help. 
“If you are at home, the best thing to do right now is to shelter in place, or in other words, stay where you are,” Costilla County Commissioner Lawrence Pacheco said in a statement. 
Costilla County says those who are stuck and have health or other safety needs can call 719-480-8719. Those in an immediate emergency should call 911. Tags: Jesse Paul Breaking news reporter.
